Contour integralï¼ˆè·¯å¾‘ç©åˆ†ï¼‰

ä¾‹é¡Œ1

è¨ˆç®— \[\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\frac{d\theta}{5+3\cos \theta}\]

å¾®ç©åˆ†åšæ³•ï¼šlet\(u=\tan \frac{\theta}{2}\cdots\)

ç•™æ•¸åšæ³•

\[z=e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta+i\sin\theta\]

\[\bar{z}=e^{-i\theta}=\cos\theta-i\sin\theta\]

\(|z|=1\), \(\bar{z}=\frac{1}{z}\)

\[\cos\theta=\frac{1}{2}(z+\bar{z})=\frac{1}{2}(z+\frac{1}{z})\]

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\frac{d\theta}{5+3\cos \theta}&=\int_C\frac{dz}{iz(5+\frac{3}{2}(z+\frac{1}{z}))}\\ &=\frac{1}{i}\int_C\frac{dz}{\frac{3}{2}z^2+5z+\frac{3}{2}}\\ &=\frac{2}{i}\int_C \frac{dz}{3z^2+10z+3}\\ &=\frac{2}{i}\int_C\frac{dz}{(3z+1)(z+3)}\\ &=4\pi \cdot \underbrace{\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_C\frac{dz}{(3z+1)(z+3)}}_{Res\left(\frac{1}{(3z+1)(z+3)};-\frac{1}{3}\right)}\end{aligned}\]

\(\frac{1}{(3z+1)(z+3)}\)æœ‰å…©å€‹simplepoleï¼Œåˆ†åˆ¥åœ¨\(z=-3,-\frac{1}{3}\)ï¼Œå› ç‚ºå–®ä½åœ“åŠå¾‘æ˜¯1ï¼Œ\(z=-3\)åœ¨ç©åˆ†ç¯„åœå¤–ï¼Œåªå‰©ä¸‹\(-\frac{1}{3}\)

\[Res=\lim_{z\rightarrow-\frac{1}{3}}(z+\frac{1}{3})\frac{1}{(3z+1)(z+3)}=\lim_{z\rightarrow-\frac{1}{3}}\frac{1}{3z+9}=\frac{1}{8}\]

\[\therefore \int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\frac{d\theta}{5+3\cos\theta}=\frac{4\pi}{8}=\frac{\pi}{2}\]

ä¾‹é¡Œ2

è¨ˆç®— \[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}dx\]

æ¢ä»¶ï¼š\(P,Q\) real-valuedpolynomials, s.t.

  1. \(Q(x)\neq 0, x\in\mathbb{R}\)
  2. \(\deg Q\geqslant 2+\deg P\)

ä¾‹é¡Œ2.1

\[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{1+x^4}\]

å¾®ç©åˆ†æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

\[x^4+1=x^4+2x^2+1-2x^2=(x^2+1)^2-2x^2=(x^2+\sqrt{2}x+1)(x^2-\sqrt{2}x+1)\]

ç•™æ•¸æ–¹æ³•ï¼š

æ–¹æ³•ä¸€

ç•«åŠåœ“

å…ˆç®—å¥‡ç•°é»\(z^4+1=0\Rightarrowz^4=-1=e^{\pi i}\)

\[z=e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}, e^{\frac{3}{4}\pi i}, e^{\frac{5}{4}\pi i},e^{\frac{7}{4}\pi i}\]

\[\int_{\Gamma}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}=2\pi iRes\left(\frac{1}{1+z^4};e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i},e^{\frac{3}{4}\pi i}\right)\]

\[Res\ at\ e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}=\lim_{z\rightarrowe^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}}(z-e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i})\frac{1}{z^4+1}=\lim_{z\rightarrowe^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}}\frac{1}{\frac{z^4+1-0}{z-e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}}}=\frac{1}{(z^4+1)'\vert_{z=e^{\frac{\pi}{4}i}}}=\frac{1}{4e^{\frac{3}{4}\pi i}}=\frac{1}{4}e^{-\frac{3}{4}\pi i}=\frac{1}{4}(\cos \frac{3}{4}\pi-i\sin \frac{3}{4}\pi)\]

\[Res\ at\ e^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}=\lim_{z\rightarrowe^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}}(z-e^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i})\frac{1}{z^4+1}=\lim_{z\rightarrowe^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}}\frac{1}{\frac{z^4+1-0}{z-e^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}}}=\frac{1}{(z^4+1)'\vert_{z=e^{\frac{3\pi}{4}i}}}=\frac{1}{4e^{\frac{9}{4}\pi i}}=\frac{1}{4}e^{-\frac{9}{4}\pi i}=\frac{1}{4}e^{-\frac{\pi}{4} i}=\frac{1}{4}(\cos \frac{1}{4}\pi-i\sin \frac{1}{4}\pi)\]

\(e^{-\frac{9}{4}\pi i}=e^{-\frac{\pi}{4}i}\)æ˜¯å› ç‚º\(e^{2\pii}=1\)ï¼ŒæŠŠå…©å€‹é»çš„ç•™æ•¸ç›¸åŠ 

\[\therefore \int_{\Gamma}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}=2\pi i\times\frac{1}{4}(-2i\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2})=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\pi\]

\[\int_{-R}^R\frac{dx}{1+x^4}+\int_{\Gamma_R}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\pi\]

ä¸‹é¢è­‰æ˜\(R\rightarrow\infty\)æ™‚ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒé …è¶¨è¿‘æ–¼0

\[\lim_{R\rightarrow\infty}\left|\int_{\Gamma_R}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}\right|\leqslant\lim_{R\rightarrow\infty}\int_0^{\pi}\frac{Rd\theta}{|1+z^4|}\leqslant\lim_{R\rightarrow\infty}\int_0^{\pi}\frac{2Rd\theta}{R^4}=\lim_{R\rightarrow\infty}\frac{2\pi}{R}=0\]

where \(|1+z^4|\geqslant\frac{|z^4|}{2}=\frac{R^4}{2}\)

æ–¹æ³•äºŒ

ç•«å››åˆ†ä¹‹ä¸€åœ“

\[\int_{\Gamma}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}=2\pi i\cdotRes\left(\frac{1}{1+z^4};e^{\frac{1}{4}\pi i}\right)=2\pi i\cdot\frac{1}{4}e^{-\frac{3}{4}\pi i}=\frac{2\pi i}{4}(\cos\frac{3}{4}\pi-i\sin \frac{3}{4}\pi)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\pi (1-i)\]

\[\int_{\Gamma}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}=\int_{\Gamma_1}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}+\int_{\Gamma_3}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}+\int_{\Gamma_R}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}\]

\[\Downarrow\]

\[\int_0^R\frac{dx}{1+x^4}+\int_R^0\frac{idy}{1+y^4}+\underbrace{\int_{\Gamma_R}\frac{dz}{1+z^4}}_{\xrightarrow{R\rightarrow\infty}0}=(1-i)\int_0^R\frac{dx}{1+x^4}\xrightarrow{R\rightarrow\infty}(1-i)\int_0^{\infty}\frac{dx}{1+x^4}\]

\[\because (1-i)\int_0^{\infty}\frac{dx}{1+x^4}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\pi(1-i)\]

\[\therefore \int_0^{\infty}\frac{dx}{1+x^4}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{4}\pi\]

Residueï¼ˆç•™æ•¸ï¼‰

Let \(z_0\) be a singularity of\(f\), let \(C\) be a simple closed curve (positivelyoriented), s.t. \(z_0\) is surroundedby \(C\) and \(f\) is holomorphic on \(U\verb|\|\{z_0\}\) and \(C\subset U\verb|\|\{z_0\}\)

Theo (residue)

\(C\) surrounds \(z_1,\cdots,z_k\), Then

\[\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_Cf(z)dz=\sum_{j=1}^k\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{C_j}f(z)dz\]

\(z_0\): pole, å‰‡

\[f(z)=\frac{C_{-m}}{(z-z_0)^m}+\cdots+\frac{C_{-1}}{z-z_0}+h(z)\]

\[\begin{aligned} residue&=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{C_{\varepsilon}}f(z)dz\\ &=\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{C_{\varepsilon}}\left(\frac{C_{-m}}{(z-z_0)^m}+\cdots+\frac{C_{-1}}{z-z_0}\right)dz\\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_0^{2\pi} \left(\frac{C_{-m}}{(\varepsilone^{i\theta})^m}+\cdots +\frac{C_{-1}}{\varepsilone^{i\theta}}\right)i\varepsilon e^{i\theta}d\theta\\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi }\int_0^{2\pi }\left(\frac{C_{-m}}{(\varepsilone^{i\theta})^{m-1}}+\cdots +\frac{C_{-2}}{\varepsilone^{i\theta}}+C_{-1}\right)d\theta\end{aligned}\]

  1. å¦‚æœæ˜¯single pole, i.e. \(\displaystylef(z)=\frac{C_{-1}}{z-z_0}+h(z)\)

\[z_0ç•™æ•¸=\lim_{z\rightarrow z_0}(z-z_0)f(z)\]

å› ç‚º

\[(z-z_0)f(z)=C_{-1}+(z-z_0)h(z)\rightarrow C_{-1}\]

  1. å¦‚æœæ˜¯order of the pole m>1

\[z_0ç•™æ•¸=\lim_{z\rightarrowz_0}\frac{1}{(m-1)!}\frac{d^{m-1}}{dz^{m-1}}[(z-z_0)^mf(z)]\]

å› ç‚º

\[f(z)=\frac{C_{-m}}{(z-z_0)^m}+\cdots+\frac{C_{-1}}{z-z_0}+h(z)\]

\[(z-z_0)^mf(z)=C_{-m}+C_{-m+1}(z-z_0)+\cdots+C_{-1}(z-z_0)^{m-1}+(z-z_0)^mh(z)\]

\(\infty\)ä¸Šçš„ç•™æ•¸

å¦‚æœåœ¨\(\infty\)è™•è§£æï¼Œå‰‡ç•™æ•¸ç‚º0ã€‚è‹¥æ˜¯singularityï¼Œå‰‡

  1. removable: \(Res=0\)
  2. pole: \(Res=C_{-1}\)
  3. essential: \(Res=C_{-1}\)

åˆ¤æ–·\(\infty\)æ˜¯å“ªé¡å¥‡ç•°é»

\[f \text{ at } \infty\Leftrightarrow f(\frac{1}{z})\text{ at }0\]

\[\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{|z|=R,\circlearrowright}f(z)dz\overset{w=\frac{1}{z}}{=\!=\!=}\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{|w|=\frac{1}{R},\circlearrowleft}f(\frac{1}{w})(-\frac{1}{w^2}dw)\]

where \(z=\frac{1}{w}\), \(dz=-\frac{1}{w^2}dw\)

å› æ­¤

\[Res[f(z),\infty]=Res[-\frac{1}{w^2}f(\frac{1}{w}),0]\]

é€™è£¡\(R\)éå¸¸å¤§ï¼Œå–å€’æ•¸å¾Œ\(\frac{1}{R}\)éå¸¸å°ï¼ŒæŠŠåŸæœ¬çš„ç„¡çª®é é»æ‹‰å›åˆ°0

denote \(z=Re^{i\theta}\), then

\[w=\frac{1}{Re^{i\theta}}=\frac{1}{R}e^{-i\theta}=\frac{1}{R}e^{i(-\theta)}\]

æ‰€ä»¥ç„¡çª®é æ™‚æ˜¯é€†æ™‚é‡ï¼Œå–å€’æ•¸å¾Œè®Šé †æ™‚é‡

e.g.

\[\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\circlearrowright}zdz=0\]

å³é‚Šè®Šæˆ\(-\frac{1}{w^2}f(\frac{1}{w})=(-\frac{1}{z^2})\frac{1}{z}=-\frac{1}{z^3}\),residue at 0

\[\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\circlearrowleft}-\frac{1}{z^3}dz=0\]

vuè€å¸«èªªï¼Œæ¢ä»¶åå°„å•¦ï¼š\(\displaystyle\frac{1}{i}=-i\)

\([ICA-1.17]\) Show that the sum ofthe \(n\) n-th roots of every nonzerocomplex number \(w\) is zero. (The nnth roots of \(w\) are the roots of theequation \(z^n-w=0\).)

The sum of the roots of a polynomial equation \(z^n+a_{n-1}z^{n-1}+\cdots +a_0\) is \(-a_{n-1}\) (Proof),in \(z^n-w=0\), \(a_{n-1}=0\), therefore proved.

\([ICA-2.1]\) Show thatCauchy-Riemann equations can also be written as

\[\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial v}{\partial y},\quad\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=-\frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \Rightarrow\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}=-i\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\]

\([ICA-2.3]\) \(f(z)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y)\), show that if \(U(z_0,\delta)\in C^1\), and satisfiesCauchy-Riemann equation, then has derivatives at \(z_0\)

\[\begin{aligned} f(z)-f(z_0)&=(x-x_0)u_1+(y-y_0)u_2+i[(x-x_0)v_1+(y-y_0)v_2]+o(z-z_0)\\ &=(x-x_0)(u_1-iu_2)+(y-y_0)(u_2+iu_1)+o(z-z_0)\\ &=(z-z_0)(u_1-iu_2)+o(z-z_0)\end{aligned}\]

\[\Rightarrow f'(z_0)=\lim_{z\rightarrowz_0}\frac{f(z)-f(z_0)}{z-z_0}=u_1-iu_2\overset{also}{=}v_2+iv_1\]

\([ICA-2.4]\)

\[\begin{aligned} &\frac{\partial f}{\partial r}=U_r+iV_r\\ &\frac{\partial f}{\partial r}=\frac{\partial f}{\partialz}\cdot \frac{\partial z}{\partial r}=f'(z)\cdot e^{i\theta}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} &\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta}=U_{\theta}+iV_{\theta}\\ &\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta}=\frac{\partial f}{\partialz}\cdot \frac{\partial z}{\partial \theta}=f'(z)\cdot ire^{i\theta}\end{aligned}\]

\[\Rightarrow U_r+iV_r=\frac{1}{ir}(U_{\theta}+iV_{\theta})\]

æ•´ç†å¾Œï¼Œè¨˜å¾—\(\Re=\Re,\Im=\Im\)

\([ICA-2.5]\)

note: \(z=(x,y)\in \bar{D}\),therefore \((x,-y)\in D\) satisfiesCauchy-Riemann as given

\([ICA-2.6]\)

note: replace \(r\rightarrowR^2/r\)

\[U_1(\frac{R^2}{r},\theta)=\frac{r}{R^2}V_2(\frac{R^2}{r},\theta)\]

\([ICA-2.8,2.9]\)

\([ICA-3.9]\) Prove: for \(\displaystyle\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}a_k(z-z_0)^k\), the formula of radius ofconvergence \(R\) is

\[\frac{1}{R}=\limsup_{n\rightarrow \infty}|a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}\]

pf. æ€è·¯ï¼šæ¹Š\(|a_nz^n|\)ï¼Œè·Ÿ1æ¯”è¼ƒ

  1. \(0<R<\infty\)

By \(\displaystyle\frac{1}{R}=\limsup_{n\rightarrow\infty}|a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}\)

For all \(n\) largeenough

\[|a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}<\frac{1}{R}+\varepsilon =\frac{1}{R-\varepsilon}\]

\[|a_n|<\frac{1}{(R-\varepsilon)^n}\]

For \(z<R\), therefore \(z<R-\varepsilon\)

\[|a_nz^n|<(\frac{z}{R-\varepsilon})^n<1 \ \square\]

For infinite \(n\)

\[|a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}>\frac{1}{R}-\varepsilon=\frac{1}{R+\varepsilon}\]

\[|a_n|>\frac{1}{R+\varepsilon}^n\]

For \(|z|>R\), also \(|z|>R+\varepsilon\)

\[|a_nz^n|>(\frac{z}{R+\varepsilon})^n>1 \ \square\]

  1. \(R=0\)

\(\Rightarrow\frac{1}{R}=\infty\)

\[|a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}>K,\ \forall K\]

choose

\[|z|>\frac{1}{K}\]

In order to let

\[|a_nz^n|>(Kz)^n>1 \ \square\]

  1. \(R=\infty\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{R}=0\)

\[\therefore |a_n|^{\frac{1}{n}}<\varepsilon \Rightarrow|a_n|<\varepsilon^n\]

choose

\[z<\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\]

Inorder to let

\[|a_nz^n|<(z\varepsilon)^n<1 \ \square\]

\([ICA-3.10(c)]\) Find convergence\(R\) for

\[1+3z+2z^2+9z^3+\cdots+2^nz^{2n}+3^{n+1}z^{2n+1}+\cdots\]

the formula for \(1/R\) yields \(R = 3^{-1/2}\) (the terms of even indexdon't have any influence), why?

\([ICA-3.11]\) Let \(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}a_kz^k\) have radius ofconvergence \(R\) and let \(m\) be a positive integer. Show thatseries

\[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}k^ma_kz^k\]

and

\[\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}k(k-1)\cdots(k-m) a_kz^k\]

both have radius of convergence \(R\)

Theo (Mean value theorem)

\(D\subset \mathbb{C}\) domain,\(f\in O(D)\), let \(p\in D\), then provided that \( ar{B}(p;r)\subset D\), we have

pf.

write \(w=p+re^{i heta}\)

\[ egin{aligned} f(p)&= rac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{C_r} rac{f(w)}{w-p}dw\ &= rac{1}{2\pii}\int_0^{2\pi} rac{f(p+re^{i heta})}{re^{i heta}}ire^{i heta}d heta\ &= rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}f(p+re^{i heta})d heta\end{aligned}\]

Theo (Maximum modulusprinciple)

\(D\subset \mathbb{C}\) domain,\(f\in O(D)\), Then \(|f|\) cannot attain local maximum in \(D\), unless \(f\) is a constant

pf. å¦‚æœmoduluså–åˆ°äº†local maximï¼Œè¦è­‰æ˜æ˜¯å¸¸æ•¸

let \(0<r<R\)

\[ egin{aligned} |f(z_0)|=| rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}f(p+re^{i heta})d heta|&\leqslant rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}|f(p+re^{i heta})|d heta \ &\leqslant rac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}|f(z_0)|d heta=|f(z_0)|\end{aligned}\]

\[|f(z_0+re^{i heta})|=|f(z_0)| \quad orall heta, \ 0<r<R\]

\[|f(z)|=const\quad z\in B(z_0;R)\]

\[ herefore |f(z)|^2=const\]

\[ herefore rac{\partial^2}{\partial z\partial ar{z}}|f(z)|^2= rac{\partial^2}{\partial z\partial ar{z}}(f(z) ar{f}(z))\overset{?}{=}| rac{\partial f}{\partialz}|^2=0\]

\[f(z)=const\quad on \ B(z_0;R)\]

\[ herefore f(z)=const\quad on \ D \ (å”¯ä¸€é›†)\]

Riemann's theorem onremovable singularity

\(D\subset \mathbb{C}\), domain,\(z_0\in D\), \(f\in O(D)\verb|\|\{z_0\}\) and \(|f|\) is bounded on \(D\verb|\|\{z_0\}\)

Then \(f\) can be redefined at \(z_0\) s.t, the function still denoted by\(f\) is holoporphic in \(D\) i.e. \(f\inO(D)\)

pf. Consider

\[g(z)=(z-z_0)^2f(z)\quad z\in D\verb|\| \{z_0\}\quad \star\]

\[g(z_0)=0\quad herefore g\in C(D)\]

\[\lim_{z ightarrow z_0}= rac{g(z)-g(z_0)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{z ightarrow z_0} rac{(z-z_0)^2f(z)}{z-z_0}=\lim_{z ightarrow z_0}(z-z_0)f(z)=0\]

\(g\)æ¯å€‹é»éƒ½å¯ä»¥å¾®åˆ†

\(\varphi\in O(D)\)

é™¤äº†åŒ—æ¥µä¹‹å¤–æœ‰ä¸€å€‹æœ‰ç•Œçš„è§£æå‡½æ•¸ï¼ŒåŒ—æ¥µæ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€é¡å¥‡ç•°é»ï¼ˆå› ç‚ºå‘¨åœéƒ½æœ‰ç•Œï¼‰ï¼Œç”¨Riemannçš„æ–¹æ³•è™•ç†å®Œ

ä¸€å€‹é€£çºŒå‡½æ•¸åœ¨ç·Šç·»çš„é›†åˆä¸Šä¸€å®šæœ‰æ¥µå¤§å€¼ï¼Œç›¸å°æ–¼é™„è¿‘çš„opensetæ˜¯å…§é»ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥\(|f|\)åœ¨ä¸€å€‹å…§é»å–åˆ°æ¥µå¤§å€¼ã€‚å¯æ˜¯ç”±æœ€å¤§æ¨¡å®šç†ï¼Œå¼·è¿«\(f\)åœ¨neighborhoodä¸Šè®Šæˆå¸¸æ•¸ï¼Œå†ç”±æ†ç­‰å®šç†ï¼Œå®ƒåœ¨\(\mathbb{C}\)ä¸Šå°±æ˜¯å¸¸æ•¸å‡½æ•¸ã€‚

ç¬¬äºŒé¡

\(|f(z)| ightarrow \infty\) as\(z ightarrow z_0\)

i.e. \( orall M>0, \ |f(z)|\geqslantM>0,\ when \ z\in B(z_0;\varepsilon)\verb|\| \{z_0\}\)

entry.content:
Power series

Theo Let \(D\) be a domain in\(\mathbb{C}\). If \(f\in O(D)\), then \(f\in C^{\omega}(D)\)

\(C^{\omega}(D)\) means locallyfunction can be represented by a power series \( lacklozenge\)

\(\Gamma=\partial B(z_0;R)\)

\(f\in O(D)\) \[ herefore \exists R>0, s.t. ar{B}(z_0;R)\subset D\]

If \(z\in B(z_0;R)\), \(w\in \Gamma\). Then \[ egin{aligned} f(z)&= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{w-z}dw\ &= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{w-z_0-(z-z_0)}dw\end{aligned}\]

If \(\exists r>0\)ï¼Œ \(s.t. \ |z-z_0|\leq r<R\). Then

\[ egin{aligned} &= rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{\Gamma} rac{1}{w-z_0} rac{f(w)}{1- rac{z-z_0}{w-z_0}}dw\ &= rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{\Gamma} rac{1}{w-z_0}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left( rac{z-z_0}{w-z_0} ight)^k ight)f(w)dw\quad \ast\ &=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\left( rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z_0)^{k+1}}dw ight)(z-z_0)^k\quad\ast\ast\ &=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}a_k(z-z_0)^k\end{aligned}\]

i.e. \(\displaystyle a_k= rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z_0)^{k+1}}dw\)

From \(\ast\) to \(\ast\ast\)ï¼Œuse Math Analysi (II)

\[f(z)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{w-z}dw\]

\[f'(z)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z)^2}dw\]

\[f''(z)= rac{2}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z)^3}dw\] \[\vdots\]

\[f^{(k)}(z)= rac{k!}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z)^{k+1}}dw\]

\[ herefore a_k= rac{f^{(k)}(z_0)}{k!}\]

\[\Rightarrow f(z)= rac{f^{(k)}(z_0)}{k!}(z-z_0)^k\]

è§£æå»¶æ‹“

\(a_k\)çš„å€¼è·Ÿ\(R\)æ²’é—œç³»ï¼Œåœ“ç›¤å¯ä»¥ä»»æ„å¤§å°ã€‚æœ‰å¯èƒ½å‡ºç¾å±•é–‹å¾Œè¶…å‡ºdomainï¼šè§£æå»¶æ‹“ï¼ˆholomorphiccontinuationï¼‰

Ex.

\[f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}z^k \Rightarrow rac{1}{1-z}\]

\(z<1\)æ™‚æ”¶æ–‚ï¼Œ\(z\geq 1\)æ™‚ç™¼æ•£

åœ¨\(z=- rac 12\)å±•å¼€ï¼Œ \[f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}b_k(z+ rac{1}{2})^k\]

åœ¨\(|z+ rac 12|< rac32\)ä¸Šçµ±çµ±æ”¶æ–‚

Cauchy Estimate

Theo Cauchy's estimate

let \(M=\max_{|z-z_0|\leq R}|f|\)

Then

\[|a_k|\leq rac{M}{R^k}. \ lacklozenge\]

\[|a_k|=| rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma} rac{f(w)}{(w-z_0)^{k+1}}dw|\leq rac{1}{2\pi}\cdot M\cdot rac{2\pi R}{R^{k+1}}= rac{M}{R^k}\]

æ§åˆ¶äº†å‡½æ•¸å€¼å°±èƒ½æ§åˆ¶ç³»æ•¸\(a_k\)

Liouvilleå®šç†

f: entire function if \(f\inO(\mathbb{C})\)

e.g. \(e^x,\sin x, p(x)\)polynomial

\[e^z=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} rac{z^k}{k!}\]

\[\sin x= rac{e^{iz}-e^{-iz}}{2i},\quad \cos z= rac{e^{iz}+e^{-iz}}{2}\]

Theo (Liouville)

Any bounded entire functions is constant \( lacklozenge\)

pf. 1

\[f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}a_kz^k,\quad |f(z)|\leq M, orallz\in\mathbb{C}\]

\[ herefore |a_k|\leq rac{M}{R^k}\]

å½“\(k\geqslant 1\)æ—¶,

\[|a_k|\leqslant \lim_{R ightarrow \infty} rac{M}{R^k}=0\]

\[ herefore f(z)=f(0)\ lacksquare\]

pf. 2

\(z\in \mathbb{C}\), choose \(R>|z|\)

\[ egin{aligned} |f(z)-f(0)|&= igg| rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{|w|=R} rac{f(w)}{w-z}dw- rac{1}{2\pii}\int_{|w|=R} rac{f(w)}{w}dw igg|\ &= igg| rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|w|=R}( rac{1}{w-z}- rac1w)f(w)dw igg|\ &\leqslant rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|w|=R}| rac{z}{w(w-z)}|\cdot|f(w)|\cdot |dw|\ &\leqslant rac{1}{2\pi i}\cdot M\cdot rac{|z|}{R(R-|z|)}\cdot 2\pi R\ &= rac{M|z|}{i(R-|z|)} ightarrow 0\quad (R ightarrow \infty)\blacksquare\end{aligned}\]

\((w-z)\)é‚Šç•Œåˆ°åœ“å…§ä¸€é»çš„è·é›¢ä¸€å®š\(\geqslant R-|z|\)

Theo (Fundamental theorem of algebra)

let \(p(z)\) be a complex-valuedpolynomial of \(\deg P\geqslant1\).

Then \(\exists w\in \mathbb{C}, \ s.t.\p(w)=0\) \( lacklozenge\)

pf. \(p(z)=az+b\quad a eq 0\),\(w=- rac{b}{a}\)

pf. 1

Assume \(p(z) eq 0, orall z\in\mathbb{C}\)

\[ herefore q(z)= rac{1}{p(z)}\in O(\mathbb{C})\]

\[ egin{aligned} |q(z)|&= rac{1}{|a_kz^k+a_{k-1}z^{k-1}+\cdots+a_1z+a_0|}\ &= rac{1}{|z|^k\cdot|a_k+ rac{a_{k-1}z^{k-1}+\cdots+a_1z+a_0}{z^k}|}\ &\leqslant rac{2}{|a_k|\cdot |z|^k}\end{aligned}\]

æœ€å¾Œä¸€æ­¥æ˜¯å› ç‚º \[ rac{|a_k|}{2}\leqslant|a_k+ rac{a_{k-1}z^{k-1}+\cdots+a_1z+a_0}{z^k}|\]

å½“\(z ightarrow \infty\)æ—¶ï¼Œ\(|q(z)| ightarrow 0\)

\( herefore q\) is bounded,entire

By Liouville, \(q\equiv c\),const

pf. 2 ç”¨æœ€æ ¹æœ¬çš„Cauchyå®šç†è­‰

Assume \(p(z) eq 0, orall z\in\mathbb{C}\) and \( ig[\)\(p(x)\) is real if \(z=x\in \mathbb{R}\)\( ig]\).

If \([ \ ]\) does not hold, thenconsider \(p(z) ar{p}(z)=Q(z)\), \[ ar{p}(z)= ar{a_k}z^k+ ar{a_{k-1}}z^{k-1}+\cdots+ ar{a_1}z+ ar{a_0}\]

Set

\[I=\int_0^{2\pi} rac{d heta}{p(2\cos heta)} eq 0\]

åœ¨\( heta\in[0,2\pi]\)ä¸Šï¼Œ\(2\cos heta\in [-1,1]\)ï¼Œ\(I eq 0\)æ²’æœ‰å•é¡Œ

\[ egin{aligned} p(2\cos heta)&=a_k(z+ rac{1}{z})^k+a_{k-1}(z+ rac{1}{z})^{k-1}+\cdots+a_1(z+ rac{1}{z})+a_0\ &= rac{1}{z^k}Q(z)\end{aligned}\]

If \(z=0\), \(Q(0)=a_k eq 0\)ï¼Œæœ€é«˜æ¬¡ä¿‚æ•¸ä¸ç‚º0

If \(z eq 0\), \(p(2\cos heta)\)ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸ªå¤šé¡¹å¼ï¼Œ\(p(2\cos heta) eq 0\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥\(Q(z) eq 0\)

entry.content:
è¤‡è®Šæœ€é‡è¦çš„å…©å€‹å®šç†ï¼

Theo :(Cauchy's integral formula) Let \(D\) be a bounded domain in \(\mathbb{C}\) with piecewise smoothdoundary. Suppose \(f\inC^1(\bar{D})\), Then \[f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partialD}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw-\frac{1}{\pi}\iint_D\frac{\displaystyle{\frac{\partial f}{\partial\bar{z}}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy,\quad \forall w\in D\]

where \(z=x+iy\).

consider \(D_{\varepsilon}=D/\bar{B_{\varepsilon}}\),\(B_{\epsilon}=B(w;\epsilon)\)

æŒ–æ‰åœ“ç›¤åæœ‰å…§å¤–ä¸¤å€‹é‚Šç•Œï¼Œæ›²ç·šç©åˆ†ç­‰äºå¤–åœçš„æ¸›å…§åœçš„

\[\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partialD_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz&=2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\partial}{\partial\bar{z}}\left(\frac{f(z)}{z-w}\right)dxdy \\ &=2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial\bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy \quad \star\end{aligned}\]

\[\oint_{\partial D_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz=\oint_{\partialD}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz-\oint_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz\quad \star\]

set \(z=w+\epsilon e^{i\theta}\),\(z-w=\epsilon e^{i\theta}\)

\[\begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz&=\oint_{\partialB_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})}{\epsilon e^{i\theta}}dz\\ &=\int_0^{2\pi} \frac{f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})}{\epsilone^{i\theta}}i\epsilon e^{i\theta}d\theta\\ &=i\int_0^{2\pi}f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})d\theta\\ &\xrightarrow{\epsilon\rightarrow0} i\int_0^{2\pi}f(w)d\theta\\ &=2\pi if(w)\end{aligned}\]

ä¸‹é¢è€ƒæ…®é€™å€‹ç©åˆ†

\[2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial\bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\]

å› ä¸º\(f\)æ˜¯\(C^1\)å‡½æ•°ï¼Œ\(\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)\inC(\bar{D})\)

CauchyKernel

\[\iint_K \bigg| \frac{1}{z-w} \bigg| dxdy<\infty\]

K: compact

å› ç‚ºæœƒæ”¶æ–‚(ç”¨æ¥µåº§æ¨™)

\[\iint_B\frac{1}{|z|}dxdy=\int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_0^R\frac 1r rdrd\theta\]

let \(\epsilon\rightarrow 0\)

\[2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial\bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\rightarrow 2i\iint_{D}\frac{\frac{\partialf}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\]

æ‰€ä»¥\(\epsilon\rightarrow 0\)æ™‚

\[\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz-2\piif(w)=2i\iint_{D}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\]

\[\therefore f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partialD}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw-\frac{1}{\pi}\iint_D\frac{\displaystyle{\frac{\partial f}{\partial\bar{z}}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\quad \blacksquare\]

Theo Let \(D\subset \mathbb{C}\) be a simply-connecteddomain, suppose \(f\in C^1(D)\capO(D)\). Then \[f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw\quad w\in\Omega\]

\(\Omega\): region surrounded by thesimple closed curve \(C\)

simply connected æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†ä¿è­‰\(C\)åœå‡ºä¾†çš„é‚„åœ¨\(D\)è£¡é¢ï¼Œé¿å…ä¸‹é¢é€™ç¨®æƒ…æ³

Theo (Cauchy)

Let \(D\) be a simply connecteddomain in \(\mathbb{C}\),

\(C\): simple closed curve in \(D\)

If \(f\in O(D)\). Then

\[\oint_C f(z)dz=0\]

ä¹‹å‰æœ‰\(C^1\)æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†è¨´è«¸æ–¼æ ¼æ—å®šç†ï¼Œä½†è­‰æ˜é€™å€‹å®šç†ä¸èƒ½ç”¨æ ¼æ—ï¼Œè¦ç”¨å®Œå…¨ä¸åŒçš„æƒ³æ³•

\(R\): rectangle

\(L\): length of \(\partial R\)

Claim: \(\oint_{\partialR}f(z)dz=0\)

åè­‰æ³•

Assume \(\exists R\) s.t. \[\oint_{\partial R}f(z)dz=A\neq 0\]

åˆ‡å‰²ï¼Œå°å¤§é•¿æ–¹å½¢ç©ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œç›¸ç•¶æ–¼å°å››å€‹å°é•¿æ–¹å½¢å„ç©ä¸€æ¬¡

\[\oint_Rf(z)dz=\sum_{k=1}^4\oint_{R^{(k)}}f(z)dz\]

\[\therefore \exists R_1=R^{(j)} \ \text{some }j, \quad s.t.\bigg|\oint_{\partial R_1}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4}\]

\[\bigg|\oint_{\partial R_2}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4^2}\]

obtain a seq. of rectangle \(\{R_n\}\)

\[\bigg|\oint_{\partial R_n}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4^n}\]

By Cantor intersection theorem\[\exists P_0\in R_n, \ \forall n\quad P_0\in D\]

Write near \(P_0\)

\[f(z)=f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)\]

\(\epsilon\rightarrow 0\) as \(z\rightarrow P_0\)

n å¾ˆå¤§æ™‚ï¼Œ\(f(z)\)å¯ä»¥ç”¨\(f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon(z)(z-P_0)\)æ›¿æ›

\[\oint_{\partial R_n}\left[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon(z)(z-P_0)\right]dz\]

å¤šé …å¼ä¸€å®šæ˜¯æŸå€‹å‡½æ•¸çš„å¾®åˆ†ï¼Œ \[\therefore f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)=Q'(z)\]

\(Q(z)\): polynomial of degree atmost 2

\(z=\gamma(t)\)

\[\begin{aligned} &\oint_{\partial R_n}[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)]dz\\ =&\oint_{\partial R_n}Q'(z)dz\\ =&\int_a^bQ'(z)\gamma'(t)dt\\ =&\int_a^bd(Q(z))\\ =& Q(\gamma(b))-Q(\gamma(a))=0\quad \text{é¦–å°¾ç›¸è¿}\end{aligned}\]

å› ç‚º \[|\oint_{\partial R_n}dz|=|\int_a^b\gamma'(t)dt|\leq\int_a^b|\gamma'(t)|dt=Ln\] \((z-P_0)\)å°äºç­‰äº\(Ln\)ï¼ˆåœ“å¿ƒåˆ°é‚Šç•Œçš„é€£ç·š\(\leqslant\)å‘¨é•·ï¼‰ï¼Œ\(dz\)ç©åˆ†ä¹Ÿå°æ–¼\(Ln\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å…©æ¬¡ã€‚\(\epsilon\)ç”¨æœ€å¤§å€¼æå‡ºä¾† \[\begin{aligned} &|\oint_{\partial R_n}\left[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon(z)(z-P_0)\right]dz|\\ =&|\oint_{\partial R_n}\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)dz|\\ \leq &\max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\cdot L_n^2\end{aligned}\]

ç”±äº \(\displaystyle{L_n=\frac{L}{2^n}}\)

\[\max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\cdot\left(\frac{L}{2^n}\right)^2\geq \frac{|A|}{4^n}\]

ç•¶\(n\rightarrow \infty\)æ™‚ï¼Œ\(\max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\rightarrow0\)

\[\therefore \max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\geq\frac{|A|}{L^2}\Rightarrow 0\geq \frac{|A|}{L^2}\quad \text{çŸ›ç›¾}.\]

ç›®å‰è­‰å¾—åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰çš„é•·æ–¹å½¢ä¸Š \[\oint_{\partial R}f(z)dz=0 \ \square\]

é€™å€‹å‡½æ•¸\(F(z)\)å¿…é ˆwell-definedï¼šä¸ç®¡è·¯å¾‘æ€éº¼é¸ï¼Œç©å‡ºä¾†éƒ½ä¸€æ¨£

è¦è­‰æ˜å®ƒwell-defined

\[\Leftrightarrow F(z)=\int_{\Gamma_1}f(z)dz=\int_{\Gamma_2}f(z)dz\]

å› ç‚ºæ¯æ®µè·¯å¾‘å¹³è¡Œæ–¼\(x\)æˆ–\(y\)è½´ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è¦–ä½œé•·æ–¹å½¢çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚å€ŸåŠ©å‰›æ‰çš„æº–å‚™å·¥ä½œï¼Œ

\[\int_{\Gamma_1-\Gamma_2}f(z)dz=\int_{\Gamma_1}f(z)dz-\int_{\Gamma_2}f(z)dz=0\quad\square\]

æ‰€ä»¥å®ƒæ˜¯well-defined

Claim \[F'(z)=f(z)\]

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{z\rightarrow w}\frac{F(z)-F(w)}{z-w}&=\lim_{z\rightarroww}\frac{\int_{\Gamma+C}f(\eta)d\eta-\int_{\Gamma}f(\eta)d\eta}{z-w}\\ &=\lim_{z\rightarrow w}\frac{\int_Cf(\eta)d\eta}{z-w}\\ &=\lim_{z\rightarroww}\frac{\int_Cf(w)d\eta+[\int_Cf(\eta)d\eta-\int_Cf(w)d\eta]}{z-w}\\ &=f(w)\quad \square\end{aligned}\]

\(f(w)\)æ˜¯å¸¸æ•¸ï¼Œ\(\int_Cf(w)d\eta=f(w)(z-w)\)ï¼Œå¾Œä¸€é …è¶¨æ–¼0

\[\begin{aligned} \oint_Cf(z)dz&=\oint_CF'(z)dz\\ &=\int_a^bF'(\gamma(t))\gamma'(t)dt\\ &=\int_a^b dF(\gamma(t))\\ &=F(\gamma(b))-F(\gamma(a))=0. \quad \blacksquare\end{aligned}\]

Theo(Cauchy's integral formula)

Let \(D\) be a simply-connecteddomain in \(\mathbb{C}\),

\(C\): simple closed curve

\(f\in O(D)\), let \(\Omega\) be the region surrounded by \(C\)

Then

\[f(z)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw\quad w\in \Omega\]

å€åŸŸå…§çš„é»çš„å‡½æ•¸å€¼å®Œå®Œå…¨å…¨å—é‚Šç•Œé»å‡½æ•¸å€¼çš„å½±éŸ¿ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åˆé‚Šç•Œç”Ÿæˆ

å·ç§¯ convolution \[f\rightarrow g(z)=\int f(w)g(z-w)dw\]

\(\displaystyle{\frac{1}{w-z}}\):Cauchy kernel (reproducing kernel)

\(\Omega/\bar{B_{\epsilon}}=\Omega_{\epsilon}\)

\[\int_{\partial \Omega_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw=0\]

ä¸Šä¸€å€‹å®šç†è­‰å¾—ï¼šè§£æå‡½æ•¸åœ¨å®ƒçš„é‚Šç•Œç©åˆ†ç­‰æ–¼0ï¼Œå› ç‚º\(w=z\)è¢«æŒ–æ‰äº†ï¼Œè€Œä¸”\(\displaystyle\frac{1}{w-z}\)æœ‰æ¥µé™ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥\(\displaystyle\frac{f(w)}{w-z}\)æ˜¯è§£æå‡½æ•¸

\[\int_{\partial \Omega=C}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw-\int_{\partialB_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw=0\]

å› ç‚º\(\epsilon\rightarrow 0\)æ™‚ï¼Œ\[\int_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw\rightarrow 2\pi if(z)\]

\[\int_{C}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw=2\pi if(z)\Rightarrow f(z)=\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{C}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw \quad \blacksquare\]

(Theo) Let D be a domain in \(\mathbb{C}\), let \(f_n\in O(D), n\in \mathbb{N}\), If \(f_n\) uniformly converges on compactsubsets (u.c.c.) of \(D\) to \(f\), then

\[f\in O(D) \ ä¸”\ f_n'\rightarrow f'\quad u.c.c.\ on \ D\]

åœ¨realä¸Šè€ƒæ…®\(\displaystylef_n(x)=\frac{\sin nx}{\sqrt{n}}\)ï¼Œ\(f_n\rightarrow f\equiv 0\) uniformly on\(\mathbb{R}\). ä½†\(f_n'(x)=\sqrt{n}\cos nx\), \(f'_n(0)=\sqrt{n}\)ï¼Œä¸æ”¶æ–‚æ–¼\(f\equiv 0\)

è¤‡è®Šçš„è¡¨ç¾å¾ˆä¸ä¸€æ¨£

pf.

\(f\in C(D)\), choose \(\bar{B}(z_0;\delta)\subset D\), \(z\in B(z_0;\delta)\)

\[f_n(z)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma_{\delta}}\frac{f_n(w)}{w-z}dw\]

å°ç­‰å¼å…©é‚Šæ±‚æ¥µé™\(\displaystyle\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}\)

\[f(z)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma_{\delta}}\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw\]

æ±‚å°

\[f_n'(z)=\frac{1}{2\pii}\int_{\Gamma_{\delta}}\frac{f_n(w)}{(w-z)^2}dw\]

\[n\rightarrow\infty\quad \Downarrow \quad \text{uniformly on a smallerdisc}\]

\[f'(z)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\Gamma_{\delta}}\frac{f(w)}{(w-z)^2}dw\]

ç›¸ç•¶æ–¼æ”¶æ–‚å‡½æ•¸å¾åŸä¾†çš„\(f\)è®Šæˆ\(f/(w-z)\)

entry.title: è§£æå‡½æ•¸
entry.content:
Complex numbers \(\mathbb{C}\)

\[(a,b)\quad a,b\in \mathbb{R}\]

Define operations \(+,\cdot\)

  1. \((a,b)+(c,d)=(a+c,b+d)\)
  2. \((a,b)\cdot(c,d)=(ac-bd,ad+bc)\)

\( herefore \mathbb{C}\)å½¢æˆä¸€å€‹ field

\[\mathbb{R}\quad a\in \mathbb{R}\]

\[a\mapsto (a,0)\]

\[(a,0)\cdot (c,d)=(ac,ad)\]

\[a(c,d)=(ac,ad)\]

\[(0,1)\cdot (0,1)=(0-1,0)=(-1,0)\]

Denote \((0,1)=i\), \(i^2=-1\), \(x^2+1=0\).

\[z\in \mathbb{C} ightarrow z=a+ib\]

\[ egin{aligned}z&=(a,b)\&=(a,0)+(0,b)\&=a+b(0,1)\&=a+ib\end{aligned}\]

\(a=\Re z\), real part

\(b=\Im z\), imaginary part

\(|z|=\sqrt{a^2+b^2}\), modulus

\( ar{z}=a-ib\), complexconjugate

\[z,w\in \mathbb{C}\]

Define \[d(z,w)=|z-w|\]

Thus: \(z,w\in \mathbb{C}\)

\[|z+w|\leqslant |z|+|w|\]

\((\mathbb{C},d)\): metric space

open ball centered at \(z\) withradius \(r\)

\[B(z;r)=\{w\in \mathbb{C} ig | |w-z|<r\}\]

\[f: \Omega ightarrow \mathbb{C}\quad \Omega\subset \mathbb{C}\]

\(\Omega\) æ˜¯ \(\mathbb{C}\) çš„ä¸€å€‹(connected open)domainï¼Œç¾åœ¨åœ¨\(\Omega\)ä¸Šé¸ä¸€å€‹é»

\[z_0\in \Omega\]

\(f\) is said to be differentiableat \(z_0\), if \(\displaystyle{\lim_{z ightarrowz_0} rac{f(z)-f(z_0)}{z-z_0}}\) exists, denoted by \(f'(z_0)\)

If \(f\) is diff. at every point of\(\Omega\), then we say \(f\) is a holomorphic functionï¼ˆè§£æå‡½æ•¸/å…¨ç´”å‡½æ•¸ï¼‰ on \(\Omega\).

\[O(\Omega)=\{ ext{all of the holomorphic functions on }\Omega \}\]

æœ‰\(S\subset \mathbb{C}\) set, \(f\in O(S)\) means, \(f\) is holomorphic on some openneighborhood of \(S\).

\[ rac{\partial u}{\partial x}(z_0)= rac{\partial v}{\partial y}(z_0)\]

\[ rac{\partial u}{\partial y}(z_0)=- rac{\partial v}{\partial x}(z_0)\]

Cauchy-Riemann eq.

å¯å° \(\Rightarrow\)æŸ¯è¥¿é»æ›¼æ–¹ç¨‹ï¼Œä½†æŸ¯è¥¿é»æ›¼æ–¹ç¨‹ \( Rightarrow\) å¯å°

ä¾‹.

\[u(x,y)= egin{cases}\displaystyle{ rac{x^3-y^3}{x^2+y^2}} & (x,y) eq (0,0)\0 & (x,y)= (0,0)\end{cases}\]

\[v(x,y)= egin{cases}\displaystyle{ rac{x^3+y^3}{x^2+y^2}} & (x,y) eq (0,0)\0 & (x,y)= (0,0)\end{cases}\]

\[ rac{\partial u}{\partial x}(0,0)=1, rac{\partial u}{\partialy}(0,0)=-1\]

\[ rac{\partial v}{\partial x}(0,0)=1, rac{\partial v}{\partialy}(0,0)=1\]

æ»¿è¶³æŸ¯è¥¿é»æ›¼æ–¹ç¨‹

along \(x\)-axis \[\lim rac{f(x,0)-f(0,0)}{x}= rac{x+ix-0}{x}=1+i\]

along \(x=y\) \[\lim rac{f(x,x)-f(0,0)}{x+ix}= rac{ix}{x+ix}= rac{i}{1+i}= rac{1+i}{2}\]

If \(f\in C^1(\Omega)\)

Set Cauchy-Riemann operator

\[ rac{\partial}{\partial ar{z}}= rac 12\left( rac{\partial}{\partialx}+i rac{\partial}{\partial y} ight)\]

\[ egin{aligned} rac{\partial f}{\partial ar{z}} & = rac12 \left( rac{\partial}{\partial x}+i rac{\partial}{\partial y} ight)(u+iv) \&= rac 12\left (\left ( rac{\partial u}{\partialx}- rac{\partial v}{\partial y} ight)+i\left( rac{\partialu}{\partial y}+ rac{\partial v}{\partial x} ight) ight)\&=0\end{aligned}\]

åœ¨æ»¿è¶³æŸ¯è¥¿é»æ›¼æ–¹ç¨‹çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹

\[\Leftrightarrow f\in O(\Omega)\]

è¤‡è®Šé€™é–€å­¸å•å°±æ˜¯åœ¨ç ”ç©¶é€™å€‹æ–¹ç¨‹å¼ï¼š \[ rac{\partial u}{\partial ar{z}}=g\]

\(g=0\)æ—¶ï¼Œæ˜¯è§£æå‡½æ•¸

è¬›ç‚¹å¾®ç©åˆ†ã€‚

Curve

\[\gamma: [a,b] ightarrow \mathbb{C}\]

\[t\mapsto \gamma(t)=(x(t),y(t))\]

æ‡‰è©²æ˜¯ \(t\in [a,b],\ \gamma(t)\in\mathbb{C}\)

Smooth curve \[\gamma \in C^1([a,b]), \ and \ \ \gamma'(t) eq 0\ \ on\ \ (a,b)\]

Piecewise smooth \[\gamma: [a,b] ightarrow \mathbb{C}\]

\[\exists P=\{a=t_0<t_1<\cdots <t_{n-1}<t_n=b\}\]

Def 7.1 Let \(z=f(x,y)\) define \(z\) as a function of \(x\) and \(y\) in a region \(R\). The function \(f(x,y)\) is said to be homogeneousof order n if it can be written as

\[f(x,y)=x^ng(u)\tag{7.11}\]

Homogeneous Coefficients

Definition 7.2. The differential equation \[P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy=0\tag{7.3}\] where \(P(x,y)\) and \(Q(x,y)\) are each homogeneous functions oforder \(n\) is called a firstorder differential equation with homogeneous coefficients.

Theorem 7.32. If the coefficients in \((7.3)\) are each homogeneous function oforder \(n\), then the substitution init of \((7.31),(7.33)\) will lead to anequation in which the variables are separable.

\[y=ux\ \Leftarrow \\left(u=\frac{y}{x}\right),\quad dy=udx+xdu,\quad\tag{7.31}\]

Def 9.23 \[P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy\tag{9.24}\] is called an exact differential if it is thetotal differential of a function \(f(x,y)\). \[P(x,y)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}f(x,y)\quadQ(x,y)=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}f(x,y)\tag{9.241}\]

\((10.392)\)$e{3x}dy+3e{3x}ydx=0 \(|\)e^{3x}y=c$

Integrating Factor

Def 10.5 A multiplying factor whichconverts an inexact diff eq into an exact one is calledintegrating factor.

\[\frac{\partial}{\partial y}[hP(x,y)]=\frac{\partial}{\partialx}[hQ(x,y)]\tag{10.62 $\star$}\]

  1. \(h=h(x)\)

\[\frac{dh(x)}{h(x)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partialy}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)}{Q(x,y)}dx\tag{10.64}\]

æ›´ç‰¹æ®Šåœ°ï¼Œ\(F(x)=\displaystyle{\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partialy}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)}{Q(x,y)}}\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥\(\displaystyle{h(x)=e^{\int F(x)dx}}\)

  1. \(h=h(y)\)

\[\frac{dh(y)}{h(y)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partialx}Q(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)}{P(x,y)}dy\tag{10.68}\]

  1. \(h=h(u), u=xy\)

\[\frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partialy}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partialx}Q(x,y)}{yQ(x,y)-xP(x,y)}du\tag{10.72}\]

  1. \(h=h(u),u=\frac xy\) \[\frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{y^2\left[\frac{\partial}{\partialy}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partialx}Q(x,y)\right]}{xP(x,y)+yQ(x,y)}du\tag{10.76}\]

  2. \(h=h(u),u=\frac yx\)

\[\frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{x^2\left[\frac{\partial}{\partialx}Q(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partialy}P(x,y)\right]}{xP(x,y)+yQ(x,y)}du\tag{10.76}\]

Linear DE

Def 11.1 A linear diff eq of the firstorder is \[\frac{dy}{dx}+P(x)y=Q(x)\tag{11.11}\]

Integrating factor is in the form \(\displaystyle{e^{\int P(x)dx}}\), by \((9.32)\).

\[\left[P(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}y-Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}\right]dx+e^{\intP(x)dx}dy=0\tag{11.13}\]

\[\underbrace{e^{\int P(x)dx}dy+P(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}ydx}_{d(e^{\intP(x)dx}y)}=Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx\tag{11.16}\]

\[e^{\int P(x)dx}dy=\int Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx+C\tag{11.19}\]

This is a true general solution of \((11.11)\). \[y=e^{-\int P(x)dx}\int Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx+Ce^{-\intP(x)dx}\tag{11.191}\]

Bernoulli Equation

\[\frac{dy}{dx}+P(x)y=Q(x)y^n\tag{11.5}\]

ä¸¤è¾¹åŒæ—¶ä¹˜ä»¥\((1-n)y^{-n}\) \[(1-n)y^{-n}\frac{dy}{dx}+(1-n)P(x)y^{1-n}=(1-n)Q(x)\tag{11.52}\] \[\frac{d}{dx}(\underbrace{y^{1-n}}_{u})+(1-n)P(x) \cdot\underbrace{y^{1-n}}_{u}=(1-n)Q(x)\tag{11.53}\] \(u=y^{1-n}\)ï¼Œè½¬åŒ–ä¸ºçº¿æ€§DEçš„å½¢å¼ \[u'+(1-n)P(x) \cdot u=(1-n)Q(x)\tag{11.53}\]

Definition 2.68. A set in the plane iscalled a region if it satisfies the following twoconditions: 1. Each point of the set is the center of a circle whoseentire interior consists of points of the set. 2. Every two points ofthe set can be joined by a curve (not a line) which consists entirely ofpoints of the set.

Definition 2.81. The relation \[f(x,y)=0 ag{2.82}\] defines \(y\) as animplicit function of \(x\) on an interval \(I:a<x<b\), if there exists a function\(g(x)\) defined on \(I\) such that \[f[x,g(x)]=0 ag{2.83}\] for every \(x\) in\(I\).

Definition 3.4. \(f(x)\) is a solution of the differentialequation \[F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0 ag{3.41}\]

if

\[F[x,f(x),f'(x),\cdots,f^{(n)}(x)]=0 ag{3.42}\]

Definition 3.6. A relation \(f(x,y)=0\) will be called animplicit solution of the differential equation

\[F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0 ag{3.61}\]

on an interval \(I:a<x<b\),if

  1. it defines \(y\) as an implicitfunction of \(x\) on \(I\),i.e., if there exists a function \(g(x)\) defined on \(I\) such that \(f[x,g(x)]=0\) for every \(x\) in \(I\), and if

  2. \(g(x)\) satisfies 3.61, i.e.,if

\[F[x,g(x),g'(x),\cdots,g^{(n)}(x)]=0 ag{3.62}\]

for every \(x\) in \(I\).

Question:

\((e) xy'=2y\leftarrow y=x^2\),\((x eq 0)\)

\((j)xy'+y=y^2\leftarrowy= rac{2}{x+2}\), \((x eq0,-2)\)

Definition 4.3. The functions definedby

\[y=f(x,c_1,c_2,\cdots,c_n) ag{4.31}\]

of the \(n+1\) variables, \(x,c_1,c_2,\cdots,c_n\) will be called ann-parameter family of solutions of the \(n\)th order differential equation

\[F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0 ag{4.32}\]

if \( orall c_i(i=1,\cdots,n)\),the resulting function \(f(x)\) definedby \((4.31)\) satisfies \((4.32)\). That is

\[F(x,f,f',\cdots,f^{(n)})=0 ag{4.33}\]

\(n\) order \( Leftrightarrow\) \(n\) parameter solutions

\( Rightarrow\): \((y'')^2+y^2=0\)

\( Leftarrow\): \((y'-y)(y'-2y)=0\leftarrow(y-c_1e^x)(y-c_2e^{2x})=0\)

Definition 4.66. particularsolution: does not contain arbitrary constants.

Definition 4.7. general solution:contains every particular solution

Definition 4.71. initialconditions: the \(n\) conditionsthat determine \(c_1,\cdots,c_n\), andgiven in terms of one value of the independent variable (e.g.ç»™å®š\(t=0\)æ—¶ï¼Œä½ç½®\(x=10\)ï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦\(v=20\))

Definition 5.12. If \(y=f(x)\) or \(f(x,y)=0\) defines \(y\) as a function of \(x\) which satisfies \[y'=F(x,y), \quada<x<b ag{5.11}\] then the graph of this function is calledan integral curve, it is the graph of a function whichis the solution of \((5.11)\).

Remind

\[y'=F(x,y)\Leftrightarrow ext{Direction field} ag{ODE}\]

\[y(x_0)=y_0 \Leftrightarrow ext{Point}\(x_0,y_0) ag{I.C.}\]

\[y(x) \Leftrightarrow ext{Integralcurve} ag{Solution}\]

Definition 5.4. An ordinary pointof (5.11) lies on one and only one of its integral curves.

Definition 5.41. A singular pointof (5.11) meets two requirements 1. NOT ordinary point: no/more thanone integral curve 2. at least one ordinary point \(o_0\in \cup(s_0,\varepsilon), orall\varepsilon\)

\[\sqrt{x^2+4x-3}=1-2x\]

Definition 6.13. Let \(y=f(x)\) define \(y\) as a function of \(x\) on an interval \(I\). The differential ofy, written as \(dy\) (or \(df\)) is defined by \[(dy)(x,\Delta x)=f'(x)\Delta x ag{6.14}\]

Theorem 6.2. If \(y=x\), then \[(dy)(x,\Delta x)=(dx)(x,\Delta x)=\Deltax ag{6.22}\]

\(dy\),\(dx\) are differentials, not increment.\(y,x\) after \(d\) are functions, not independentvariables

Theorem 6.3. If \(y=f(x)\) defines \(y\) as a function of \(x\) and \(x=g(t)\), \(y=f[g(t)]=F(t)\), define \(x\) and \(y\) as functions of \(t\), then \[(dy)(t,\Deltat)=f'[g(t)][g'(t)(dt)(t,\Delta t)]=f'(x)(dx)(t,\Deltat) ag{6.31}\]

Definition 6.4. For \(z=f(x,y)\), \[(dz)(x,y,\Delta x,\Delta y)= rac{\partialf(x,y)}{\partial x}\Delta x+ rac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y}\Deltay ag{6.41}\]

Theorem 6.5. For \(z=f(x,y)\), \(x=x(r,s,\cdots)\),\(y=y(r,s,\cdots)\) \[dz= rac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x}\Deltax+ rac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y}\Delta y ag{6.52}\]
